result.markdown:
--- title: "Celebrating 100 days of Gym dedication" # author: "Christopher Maronga" date: "2021-10-24" categories: [social, tidyverse, Data wrangling] image: "all_visits.PNG" #draft: true --- Because I can exercise and share! ## My word I can't help but feel a sense of pride and great accomplishment as the year comes to an end. In 2023, I committed to fitness goals which involved gym weight-lifting and outdoor running exercises, targeting at least 11km each weekend (spoiler: I only did 22km, \~ approximately 2 weekends), nevertheless, the results is a whooping 100 days of hard-work, dedication and near addiction to gym work-out. In this short article, I will share my 100 days journey, motivations and the lessons I have picked up in the process. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # Load packages for session pacman::p_load( lubridate, # handle and manage dates flextable, # for quick and neat tables ggthemes, # ggplot2 themes extension here, # manage file paths rio, # data import scales, # for the date label function tidyverse # data wrangling and viz ) # set theme for ggplot2 theme_set( theme_hc(base_size = 18) + # base size theme( legend.position = "none", # No legend, unless specified in the plot legend.title = element_blank(), # No title on the legend axis.title.y = element_text(angle = 90) # spin y title 90 degrees ) ) ``` ::: The below code below utilize the `tribble` function to create row-wise tibble of the workout data for the months beggining January 2023 to my celebration month and date. I also import an excel log (from the gym logs) capturing start and end times for all the gym workouts for the months listed. This will be used to create intersting visualization later on. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # Creating tibble for monthly workout counts # used to visualize in the latter sections workout_df <- tribble( ~ month, ~n_workouts, "2023-01", 14 , "2023-02", 13, "2023-03",05 , "2023-04", 0, "2023-05",02 , "2023-06",14 , "2023-07", 23, "2023-08", 15, "2023-09",0 , "2023-10", 14 ) # import gym logs gym_log_raw <- import(here("posts","celebrate-100-gym-days", "chris-gym_game.xlsx")) # data processing workout_df <- workout_df %>% mutate( month = ym(month), n_workouts = as.integer(n_workouts) ) ``` ::: ## Cleaning gym logs data ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # clean the gym log data gym_log <- gym_log_raw %>% # create visit date, stat time and end time mutate( visit_start_time = str_extract(visit_start, "\\d+:\\d+[aApP][mM]"), # extract time component visit_end_time = str_extract(visit_end, "\\d+:\\d+[aApP][mM]"), # extract time component visit_date = str_extract(visit_start, "\\d{2} [A-Za-z]{3} \\d{2}"), # extract date component visit_date = dmy(visit_date), # convert into ISO date week_day = wday(visit_date, label = T, abbr = T), # day of the week month = month(visit_date, label = T), # workout month duration_mins = as.integer(str_remove(duration, " minutes")), # minutes in the gym morning_wkout = ifelse(str_detect(visit_start, "am"), "Yes", "No") # Morning workout (Yes/No) ) %>% # drop the first 3 columns, not neede downstream select(-c(1:3)) %>% arrange(visit_date) gym_log %>% select(-gym_game) %>% head(n = 8) %>% flextable() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}

visit_start_time

visit_end_time

visit_date

week_day

month

morning_wkout

86

Yes

``` ::: ::: It all began with setting some realistic and achievable goals. When you are working towards a plan, you get a clear compass and guiding light that keeps you focused all the time. Some of the goals I set and working towards are:- - Improve my muscle strength \[full body muscles\] - Build endurance - Overall fitness ::: {.cell fig.dpi='300'} ```{.r .cell-code} workout_df %>% ggplot(aes(x = month, y = n_workouts, group = 1)) + geom_point(aes(size = n_workouts)) + # size of point depends on number of workouts geom_line(linewidth = 0.8) + labs(title = "Trend of monthly gym workouts", subtitle = "Past 10 months only", x = "Month", y = "No. of workouts") + scale_x_date(date_breaks = "month", # break by 1 month interval date_labels = "%b") # show only month of the year ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![Monthly Gym workouts](index_files/figure-html/fig-trajectory-1.png){#fig-trajectory width=1248} ::: ::: @fig-trajectory shows a trend of monthly workouts, with my worst efforts in the months of March and May (I have an excuse though ðŸ˜‚). I reached by best efforts in the month of July with a total of 23 gym works in that monthly only ðŸ˜°, never managed to replicate that effort, it has now since become my other additional goal, you see how it works now? ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} workout_df %>% ggplot(aes(y = n_workouts, x = factor(1))) + geom_boxplot(width = 0.2) + labs(title = "The overal picture", x = "", y = "No. of workouts") ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![Workout summary](index_files/figure-html/fig-summaries-1.png){#fig-summaries width=672} ::: ::: I averaged 10 workouts per month during the 10 months period (despite registering 0 in April and May) @fig-summaries. I registered a median of 13 workouts per month, not bad for a beginner though, proud of these numbers to the greatest heights. ## Monthly visual chart {#sec-monthviz} The cascede images below shows monthly presence in the gym. The light-green highlighted dates represents the days I worked out for that month. July has a good pattern, I love it ðŸ¤— ::: {layout-nrow=2} ![Jan](Jan2023.PNG) ![Feb](Feb2023.PNG) ![Mar](Mar2023.PNG) ![Apr](Apr2023.PNG) ![May](May2023.PNG) ![Jun](Jun2023.PNG) ![Jul](Jul2023.PNG) ![Aug](Aug2023.PNG) ![Sept](Sept2023.PNG) ![Oct](Oct2023.PNG) ::: ## Workout schedule ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # Work out schedule workout_sched <- tribble( ~ Day, ~ `50 mins`, ~ `30 mins`, ~`10 mins`, "Monday", "Chest", "Biceps", "Treadmill Run", "Tuesday", "Back", "Triceps", "Treadmill Run", "Wednesday", "Legs", "Shoulder", "Treadmill Run", "Thursday", "Core", "Compound exercises", "Treadmill Run", "Friday", NA_character_, NA_character_, "Rest day (Not always)", "Saturday", NA_character_, NA_character_, "Outdoor half-marathon 11 - 13kms") ``` ::: The table below shows the daily work-out schedule, making sure I spend more time on muscles that take long to grow and always end my workout with a 10 mins run on the treadmill. The headers are day of the week and mins allocated to each exercise. ::: {#tbl-sched .cell tbl-cap='Workout schedule'} ```{.r .cell-code} workout_sched %>% qflextable() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}

Day

50 mins

30 mins

10 mins

Monday

Chest

Biceps

Treadmill Run

Tuesday

Back

Triceps

Treadmill Run

Wednesday

Legs

Shoulder

Treadmill Run

Thursday

Core

Compound exercises

Treadmill Run

Friday

Rest day (Not always)

Saturday

Outdoor half-marathon 11 - 13kms

``` ::: ::: As a starting point, I aimed at working out for at least 1hr 30 mins; focusing two muscles a day as shown in @tbl-sched. Friday was not all rest day as can been seen in [monthly visual chart - @sec-monthviz], but was mostly a plan to catch up on missed appointment a.k.a punish yourself for missing many sessions the prior month.http://127.0.0.1:15909/graphics/plot_zoom_png?width=2327&height=1245 ## Visualizing workout game ## Average monthly workout duration ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} gym_log %>% group_by(month) %>% summarise( avg_dur = mean(duration_mins) ) %>% ggplot(aes(x = month, y = avg_dur, group = 1)) + geom_line()+ geom_point() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](index_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-8-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ## Trend - best month What is the effect of workout buddy in the trend? ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} gym_log %>% filter(month == "Jul") %>% ggplot(aes(x = visit_date, y = duration_mins, group = 1)) + geom_point()+ geom_line() + scale_x_date(date_breaks = "day", # break by 1 month interval #date_labels = "%d\n%b", labels = label_date_short()) # show only month of the year ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](index_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-9-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ## Summary - workout days What is the effect of workout buddy in the trend? ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} gym_log %>% ggplot(aes(x = month, y = duration_mins)) + geom_boxplot(width = 0.5, outlier.color = "red") ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](index_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-10-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ## Histogram of duration ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} gym_log %>% ggplot(aes(x = duration_mins)) + geom_histogram(bins = 30) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](index_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-11-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ## Conclusion and take aways This celebration is about a habit I have managed to pick, the growth and the transformation it has brought about.This type of a journey requires accountability, and for that reason, I have a workout buddy [Tony Henry](https://www.linkedin.com/in/tony-henry-43a372a0/) who I am accountable to, and the gym app was very crucial in tracking my progress. Fitness journey comes with challenges, for instance having to wake up in the morning at around 6am to workout while you would rather keep warm and sleep is the hardest choice. Overcoming this type of challenge was key to my success, made me mentally stronger and enabled me to become more resilient. Listen to your body always, know when to push harder and when to rest. Celebrate every milestone you have achieved, even if it meant you lifted 2.5kg extra on top of your regular weight limit. Celebrations makes you more energetic and looking forward to move up next level the following workout day. I hope my story inspires you to start your fitness journey or continue the one you already archived. It's doable, if you put mind to it. Here is to 100 days of hard-work, dedication and determination ðŸ™ŒðŸ¥³.
